elements.content: Reaction of tris-(2-chloroethylamine) with either para-hydroxyethylbenzoate or meta-hydroxyethylbenzoate followed by hydrolysis affords the podands tris-(4-carboxy-2-phenoxy-ethyl)amine and tris-(3-carboxy-2-phenoxy-ethyl)amine, respectively. Aqueous solutions of Cd(NO3)2·6H2O readily react with the podands in a 1:2 molar ratio in the presence of pyridine at room temperature to form the porous coordination polymers {[Cd(ptaH)]·5H2O} n (1) and {[Cd2(mtaH)2(H2O)2]·14H2O} n (2). Compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̄ with a = 10.223(7), b = 11.465(8), and c = 12.331(8) Å, α = 93.43(1)°, β = 96.67(1)°, γ = 95.08(1)°, V = 1426.4(2) Å3, Z = 2, ρcalcd = 1.65 g cm-3, T = 100 K, μ = 0.839 mm-1, R 1 = 0.0741 (I > 2σ(I)), wR 2 = 0.1636, and GOF = 1.322. Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c with a = 16.752(1), b = 18.568(1), and c = 21.610(2) Å, β = 107.36(10)°, V = 6415.8(8) Å3, Z = 4, ρcalcd = 1.58 g cm-3, T = 100 K, μ = 0.759 mm-1, R 1 = 0.0339 (I > 2σ(I)), wR 2 = 0.0861, and GOF = 1.040. Each of the coordination polymers looks like an infinite chain of metallocycles with different void spaces. These voids are occupied by supramolecularly assembled water molecules whose structures are commensurate with the metal−organic frameworks (MOFs).

elements.content:
Water clusters as discrete or infinite networks occupy the void spaces in porous metal−organic framework structures.

Introduction

Formation of metal−organic framework (MOF) structures has seen tremendous upsurge in recent years as useful materials in potential applications. Our research efforts in this area are directed toward the synthesis of open frameworks with high porosity and thermal stability. For this, we have designed and synthesized two podands (see Scheme ) bearing a carboxylate group at each terminus at the 3- or 4-positions and a long linker from the bridgehead nitrogen. A similar ligand with a carboxylate at the 2-position is available in the literature. The position of the carboxylate groups in these ligands excludes the formation of a homoleptic metal complex and provides a platform to assemble more than one metal ion, leading to an open-framework structure. The carboxylate group is known to form a variety of open framework structures because of its bridging abilities. Apart from ligand topology, the degree of structuring of the water cluster that can be imposed by its environment and vice versa is also important in the design of new MOFs via water−MOF and water−water interactions. For this, the two most important principles are that (1) the O atoms belonging to the water cluster should have a separation of 2.6−3.0 Å and (2) the cluster should optimally occupy the space available with favorable interactions with the MOF. We show that the two MOFs have different voids in terms of topology and size that are occupied by water clusters/networks of different nuclearity and structure. Discrete as well as infinite chains of hydrogen-bonded water molecules in organic and metal−organic framework structures continue to generate much interest in the scientific community because such studies facilitate our understanding of the liquid. However water remains a poorly understood liquid because the major problem lies in the correct description of hydrogen-bonding interactions and their fluctuations among a group of H2O molecules. The advantage of clusters/networks is the possibility to simply vary the size and to investigate the development of properties of the condensed phase in a step by step manner by allowing a better description of the many-body interactions.

elements.content: Of particular interest here is the structure of a discreet (H2O)10 cluster. Theoretical calculations by Buck et al. have suggested the minimum energy conformation for the decamer as an octameric cube with two water molecules fused at one of the edges, while a recent calculation showed two fused parallel pentamers to be energetically the most stable. Few decamers16 have been identified in crystal hydrates such as one with icelike diamondoid structure that has been identified16d in self-assembled metal−organic cages, while an organic host built from 5-hydroxyisothalic acid and 18-crown-616c contains decamers in the form of two fused parallel cyclic pentamers with staggered conformation. Water chains appear to be important in the control of proton fluxes in a variety of biomolecules, as well as facilitating selective permeation of water across membranes.

elements.content:
Materials. The metal salts were obtained from Aldrich and used as received. All other chemicals were procured from S. D. Fine Chemicals, India. All solvents were purified prior to use.

Physical Measurements. Spectroscopic data were collected as follows:  IR (KBr disk, 400−4000 cm-1) Perkin-Elmer model 1320; X-ray powder pattern (Cu Kα radiation at a scan rate of 3°/min, 293 K) Siefert ISODEBYEFLEX-2002 X-ray generator; thermogravimetric analysis (heating rate of 5 °C/min) Perkin-Elmer Pyris 6. Microanalyses for the compounds were obtained from the Central Drug Research Institute, Lucknow, India. FAB-MS (positive ion) data were recorded on a JEOL SX 102 /DA-6000 mass spectrometer using argon as the FAB gas at 6 kV and 10 mA with an accelerating voltage of 10 kV at 298 K. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a JEOL JNM-LA400 FT (400 MHz) instrument in DMSO-d 6 with Me4Si as internal standard. Melting points were recorded with an electrical melting point apparatus by PERFIT, India.

elements.content: Synthesis. Ligand Tris-(4-carboxy-2-phenoxy-ethyl)amine (ptaH 3 ). A mixture containing ethyl 4-hydroxybenzoate (4.9 g, 0.03 mol) and finely powdered anhydrous K2CO3 (10 g) in 40 mL of MeCN was heated to 100 °C. To the hot reaction mixture, solid tris-(2-chloroethyl)amine hydrochloride18 (2.4 g, 0.01 mol) was gradually added in portions over a period of 10 min. The reaction mixture was kept at 100 °C for 6 h, and solids were filtered off. A brown semisolid was obtained on evaporating the filtrate under vacuum. To hydrolyze the ester groups, the semisolid was dissolved in EtOH (60 mL) and stirred with 20 mL of 5 N NaOH solution for 24 h at RT. The mixture was cooled to 5 °C in an ice-bath and acidified by gradual addition of 6 N HCl while the temperature was maintained below 10 °C. The white precipitate was collected and washed with cold EtOH. The product was then recrystallized from EtOH and finally dried under vacuum. Yield:  85%. Mp:  does not melt up to 300 °C. FAB-MS, m/z (%):  509 (100) [ptaH3]+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6, TMS, 25 °C): δ (ppm) 3.2 (br, 6H, CH2), 4.2 (br, 6H, CH2), 7.5 (m, 12H, aromatic), 12.5 (br s, 3H, COOH). IR (KBr, cm-1, selected peaks):  3485 (ν(OH)), 1683 (ν(CO)). Anal. Calcd for C27H27O9N (%):  C, 63.65; H, 5.34; N, 2.75. Found:  C, 63.50; H, 5.91; N, 3.07.

elements.content: {[Cd(ptaH)] · 5H 2 O} n , 1. The tripodal ligand ptaH3 (0.13 g, 0.25 mmol) was dissolved in THF (10 mL) solution containing pyridine (2 mL). To this, an aqueous solution of Cd(NO3)2·6H2O (0.15 g, 0.38 mmol) was added dropwise, and the reaction mixture was stirred for 2 h at RT. The filtrate on slow evaporation at RT afforded colorless crystals of 1 after 7 days in ∼40% yield. Anal. Calcd for C27H35NO14Cd:  C, 45.68; H, 4.96; N, 1.97%. Found:  C, 45.93; H, 4.82; N, 1.94%.

The structure of 1 consists of one Cd(II) ion, one ptaH2- ligand, and five water molecules in the asymmetric unit (Figure ). Each metal is bonded to four carboxylates from four different ptaH2- ligands (Scheme A) where two carboxylates donate both O atoms, one carboxylate donates one O atom (the other O atom is donated to a different Cd(II) ion), while the fourth carboxylate, which is protonated, donates one O atom. The coordination geometry is distorted octahedral although bond distances (Table ) involving the metal center are similar20 to octahedral Cd(II) complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The structure of 1 consists of one Cd(II) ion, one ptaH2- ligand, and five water molecules in the asymmetric unit (Figure ). Each metal is bonded to four carboxylates from four different ptaH2- ligands (Scheme A) where two carboxylates donate both O atoms, one carboxylate donates one O atom (the other O atom is donated to a different Cd(II) ion), while the fourth carboxylate, which is protonated, donates one O atom. The coordination geometry is distorted octahedral although bond distances (Table ) involving the metal center are similar20 to octahedral Cd(II) complexes.

elements.content: In 2, the asymmetric unit contains two Cd(II) ions, two mtaH2- ligands, and 16 H2O molecules (Figure ). The ligand is bound to Cd(II) in a slightly different manner (Scheme B). Here, the metal ion is bonded to three carboxylates from three mtaH2- ligands where two carboxylates donate both their O atoms, the third carboxylate is protonated and donates a single O atom, and the sixth site is occupied by a water molecule showing an overall hexa-coordination in a slightly distorted octahedral geometry.

elements.content: The overall structure of 1 looks like an array of metallomacrocycles (Figure ) joined by the bridgehead N atom of the podand. In the macrocyclic units, the two Cd(II) ions show a distance of either 9.27 or 10.82 Å, while the distance between the bridgehead N atoms is 18.72 Å, forming an oval-shaped cavity. Two centrosymmetrically related (H2O)5 units form an overall discrete (H2O)10 cluster that occupies each cavity. The water cluster itself looks like a cyclic tetramer connected by two acyclic trimers at two opposite ends (Figure ) and is very different from the adamantanoid (H2O)10 clusters reported previously. The central cyclic tetrameric unit is quasi-planar, similar to the one predicted theoretically21 and found in several crystal hydrates.

elements.content: The overall structure of 2 is different from that of 1, although bond distances and bond angles (Table ) are similar in both structures. In 2, the carboxylate groups are oriented away from each other, which alters both the size and shape of the cavity formed from the metallocycles. The larger cycles are almost square in shape (each side close to 9 Å) where two metal-bound water molecules are pointed inside the cavity (Figure ) and are H-bonded to other water molecules forming a 3D water network. This water network is stabilized by H-bonding interactions (Table ) involving nearby carboxylate O atoms (Figure ) of the podand.

The repeat unit of the network consists of a bicyclo[3.2.2]nonane connected to a cyclic hexameric chair and a quasi-planar tetramer through sharing of two water molecules on either side. The other side of the tetramer is connected to a cyclic octamer again by sharing two water molecules (Figure ). The cyclic tetrameric cluster is slightly twisted from the planar conformation. The hexamer adopts an ice I h-like conformation, while the cyclic octameric unit resembles ice I c-like24 structure. Both these structures have been identified14a,25 in crystal hydrates.

elements.content: The interaction between the MOF and the water cluster is moderately strong in both structures. In the case of 1, thermal gravimetric analysis with 4.42 mg of sample in air shows that weight loss occurs in stages beginning at 60 °C, the loss of 12.5% corresponding to all of the water (calculated 12.7%) takes place above 250 °C, and soon after, the compound decomposes. For 2 also, weight loss (4.74 mg sample) occurs in stages beginning at 50 °C, and the loss of 19.1% corresponding to all of the water (calculated 18.9%) takes place above 260° C. Complete decomposition is achieved at ∼280 °C.

Complete decomposition is achieved at ~280 °C.

elements.content: The IR spectrum of ice23 shows the O−H stretching at 3220 cm-1, while this stretching vibration in liquid water23 appears at 3490 and 3280 cm-1. The FTIR spectrum of the compounds shows a broad band centered around 3400 cm-1 attributable to the O−H stretching frequency of the water cluster. This broad band significantly reduces on heating the compounds under vacuum (0.1 mm) at 250 °C for 3 h suggesting escape of the water molecules from the lattice. This suggests that the water clusters in 1 and 2 show an O−H stretching vibration similar to that of liquid water. Deliberate exposure to water vapor for 3 days does not lead to reabsorption of water into the lattice as monitored by FTIR spectroscopy. Each shows strong infrared absorption bands between 1350 and 1550 cm-1 that are diagnostic26 of coordinated carboxylates. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of the compounds before and after water expulsion show major changes in the peak positions, as well as their intensities. Therefore, the loss of water from the lattice leads to breakdown of the 3D structure, which is in support of the thermal analysis results.

elements.content: In summary, we have characterized two different MOF structures of Cd(II) with new tripodal ligands. The large voids present in the MOFs are not empty but contain water clusters of different nuclearity of hitherto unknown geometry, which represents yet another new mode of association of water molecules. The size and shape of these water clusters depend on the volume of the void space. In 1, a discrete decamer is found, whereas 2 contains an infinite water network made up of cyclic tetramer, hexamer, octamer, and bicyclo[3.2.2]nonane units. These water clusters act as “glue” to reinforce the coordination polymeric chains forming an overall 3D structure. Our present research efforts are directed toward synthesizing MOFs with guests other than water.

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis. Ligand Tris-(4-carboxy-2-phenoxy-ethyl)amine (ptaH 3 ). A mixture containing ethyl 4-hydroxybenzoate (4.9 g, 0.03 mol) and finely powdered anhydrous K2CO3 (10 g) in 40 mL of MeCN was heated to 100 °C. To the hot reaction mixture, solid tris-(2-chloroethyl)amine hydrochloride18 (2.4 g, 0.01 mol) was gradually added in portions over a period of 10 min. The reaction mixture was kept at 100 °C for 6 h, and solids were filtered off. A brown semisolid was obtained on evaporating the filtrate under vacuum. To hydrolyze the ester groups, the semisolid was dissolved in EtOH (60 mL) and stirred with 20 mL of 5 N NaOH solution for 24 h at RT. The mixture was cooled to 5 °C in an ice-bath and acidified by gradual addition of 6 N HCl while the temperature was maintained below 10 °C. The white precipitate was collected and washed with cold EtOH. The product was then recrystallized from EtOH and finally dried under vacuum. Yield:  85%. Mp:  does not melt up to 300 °C. FAB-MS, m/z (%):  509 (100) [ptaH3]+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6, TMS, 25 °C): δ (ppm) 3.2 (br, 6H, CH2), 4.2 (br, 6H, CH2), 7.5 (m, 12H, aromatic), 12.5 (br s, 3H, COOH). IR (KBr, cm-1, selected peaks):  3485 (ν(OH)), 1683 (ν(CO)). Anal. Calcd for C27H27O9N (%):  C, 63.65; H, 5.34; N, 2.75. Found:  C, 63.50; H, 5.91; N, 3.07.

Ligand Tris-(3-carboxy-2-phenoxy-ethyl)amine (mtaH 3 ). This ligand was prepared as a white precipitate following a procedure similar to the one adopted for ptaH3. The final product was collected after recrystallization from EtOH, followed by drying under vacuum. Yield:  75%. Mp:  does not melt up to 300 °C. FAB-MS, m/z (%):  509 (100) [mtaH3]+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6, TMS, 25 °C): δ (ppm) 3.4 (br, 6H, CH2), 4.5 (br, 6H, CH2), 7.5 (m, 12H, aromatic), 12.6 (br s, 3H, COOH). IR (KBr, cm-1, selected peaks):  3416 (ν(OH)), 1704 (ν(CO)). Anal. Calcd for C27H27O9N (%): C, 63.65; H, 5.34; N, 2.75. Found: C, 63.48; H, 5.87; N, 3.11.

{[Cd(ptaH)] · 5H 2 O} n , 1. The tripodal ligand ptaH3 (0.13 g, 0.25 mmol) was dissolved in THF (10 mL) solution containing pyridine (2 mL). To this, an aqueous solution of Cd(NO3)2·6H2O (0.15 g, 0.38 mmol) was added dropwise, and the reaction mixture was stirred for 2 h at RT. The filtrate on slow evaporation at RT afforded colorless crystals of 1 after 7 days in ∼40% yield. Anal. Calcd for C27H35NO14Cd:  C, 45.68; H, 4.96; N, 1.97%. Found:  C, 45.93; H, 4.82; N, 1.94%.

{[Cd 2 (mtaH) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ] · 14H 2 O} n , 2. The tripodal ligand mtaH3 (0.13 g, 0.25 mmol) was dissolved in THF (10 mL) containing pyridine (2 mL) by continuous stirring at RT. To this, an aqueous solution of Cd(NO3)2·6H2O (0.15 g, 0.38 mmol) was added, and the reaction mixture was stirred for 2 h at room temperature. The filtrate on slow evaporation afforded colorless crystals of 2 after 10 days in ∼37% yield. Anal. Calcd for C54H82N2O34Cd2:  C, 42.45; H, 5.40; N, 1.83%. Found:  C, 42.68; H, 5.17, N, 1.80%.

cln_elements.content:
Reaction of tris-(2-chloroethylamine) with either para-hydroxyethylbenzoate or meta-hydroxyethylbenzoate followed by hydrolysis affords the podands tris-(4-carboxy-2-phenoxy-ethyl)amine and tris-(3-carboxy-2-phenoxy-ethyl)amine, respectively. Aqueous solutions of Cd(NO3)2·6H2O readily react with the podands in a 1:2 molar ratio in the presence of pyridine at room temperature to form the porous coordination polymers {[Cd(ptaH)]·5H2O} n (1) and {[Cd2(mtaH)2(H2O)2]·14H2O} n (2). Compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̄ with a = 10.223(7), b = 11.465(8), and c = 12.331(8) Å, α = 93.43(1)°, β = 96.67(1)°, γ = 95.08(1)°, V = 1426.4(2) Å3, Z = 2, ρcalcd = 1.65 g cm-3, T = 100 K, μ = 0.839 mm-1, R 1 = 0.0741 (I > 2σ(I)), wR 2 = 0.1636, and GOF = 1.322. Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c with a = 16.752(1), b = 18.568(1), and c = 21.610(2) Å, β = 107.36(10)°, V = 6415.8(8) Å3, Z = 4, ρcalcd = 1.58 g cm-3, T = 100 K, μ = 0.759 mm-1, R 1 = 0.0339 (I > 2σ(I)), wR 2 = 0.0861, and GOF = 1.040. Each of the coordination polymers looks like an infinite chain of metallocycles with different void spaces. These voids are occupied by supramolecularly assembled water molecules whose structures are commensurate with the metal−organic frameworks (MOFs).

The interaction between the MOF and the water cluster is moderately strong in both structures. In the case of 1, thermal gravimetric analysis with 4.42 mg of sample in air shows that weight loss occurs in stages beginning at 60 °C, the loss of 12.5% corresponding to all of the water (calculated 12.7%) takes place above 250 °C, and soon after, the compound decomposes. For 2 also, weight loss (4.74 mg sample) occurs in stages beginning at 50 °C, and the loss of 19.1% corresponding to all of the water (calculated 18.9%) takes place above 260° C. Complete decomposition is achieved at ∼280 °C.

The interaction between the MOF and the water cluster is moderately strong in both structures. For 2 also, weight loss (4.74 mg sample) occurs in stages beginning at 50 °C, and the loss of 19.1% corresponding to all of the water (calculated 18.9%) takes place above 260° C. Complete decomposition is achieved at ~280 °C.
